newsitem.title: UK: Worms plagued mummies before they died - report.
newsitem.headline: Worms plagued mummies before they died - report.

text.p: Worms and other parasites plagued the ancient Egyptians, but mummies tell no tales of modern disease such as cancer or tuberculosis, researchers said on Friday.
Scans using computed tomography, electron microscopes and x-rays show little tooth decay but lots of microbial hitchhikers, the report in the Lancet medical journal said.

The dessicated remains of 4,000-year-old Egyptians have turned up the bug that causes trichonosis food poisoning, guinea worms and the parasite that causes malaria, Rosalie David of Manchester University Museum wrote.
"There is generally a notable absence of disease such as cancer, syphilis, tuberculosis and rickets, but not infrequent evidence of pathogenic parasites," she wrote.
At least two mummies had calcium deposits in their bladders, suggesting they had been infected with the parasitic worm that causes schistosomiasis or bilharzia.
And while the ancient Egyptians ate less sugar than modern people and thus had fewer cavities, they were plagued by sand particles in their bread, which wore away their tooth enamel.
